Data Card for Credit Risk Dataset

Dataset Overview

This dataset contains 100 samples, each representing an individual’s socio-economic and financial details for credit risk assessment. The target variable, y, is a binary label indicating creditworthiness: True for low risk and False for high risk.

Dataset Structure

  • Total Rows: 100
  • Total Columns: 35 (1 target column + 34 features)

Columns and Feature Types

Target Column

  • y: Boolean label indicating credit risk (True: Low risk, False: High risk)

Feature Columns

  • Categorical Variables: These are non-numeric features indicating specific statuses or categories:
    • checking_status, credit_history, purpose, savings_status, employment, personal_status, other_parties, property_magnitude, other_payment_plans, housing, job, own_telephone, foreign_worker, health_status
  • Numeric Variables: These represent numeric values associated with the applicant’s financial history:
    • duration, credit_amount, installment_commitment, residence_since, age, existing_credits, num_dependents
  • Continuous Variables: Features labeled as X_1 to X_13 which may represent embeddings or derived continuous values.

Data Summary

  • Missing Values: No missing values were detected in the sample.
  • Feature Details:
    • The categorical variables capture different applicant statuses (e.g., employment status, savings status).
    • The numeric variables provide details on financial aspects (e.g., credit_amount, age).
    • The continuous variables (X_1 to X_13) appear to be derived features, possibly from transformations or embeddings.

Recommended Usage

This dataset can be used to train models for binary classification tasks focusing on credit risk assessment. Use cases include: - Credit Scoring: Predicting applicant creditworthiness. - Financial Analysis: Assessing and analyzing socio-economic indicators in credit data.

Potential Limitations and Considerations

  1. Bias: The data may reflect socio-economic biases, potentially influencing model outcomes.
  2. Class Imbalance: If the target variable is imbalanced, it may affect model performance; applying resampling techniques or using balanced metrics is recommended.
  3. Interpretability: Derived continuous variables (X_1 to X_13) may lack intuitive interpretability, impacting explainability.

Ethical Considerations

Credit risk assessment has significant implications for applicants’ access to financial resources. Thus, ethical concerns such as fairness, transparency, and bias mitigation should be central to any model built using this dataset.

License and Acknowledgements

This dataset was generated synthetically for educational purposes and does not represent real-world credit data.
